findings.title: Unprotected constructor
findings.description: The constructor of the contract is unprotected, allowing anyone to call it and potentially cause unintended behavior.

findings.title: Unprotected owner variable
findings.description: The 'owner' variable is declared as public and can be modified by anyone, which may lead to unauthorized changes to the contract's ownership.

findings.title: Reentrancy risk in transferOwnership function
findings.description: Smart contract utilizes redundant code for transferOwnership(). Ideal transfer ownership code should look be written like:

findings.title: Reentrancy risk in claimPool function
findings.description: The claimPool function has a reentrancy risk due to the nonReentrant modifier.

findings.title: Reentrancy risk in retrieveERC20TokenStuck function
findings.description: The function retrieveERC20TokenStuck has a reentrancy risk.

findings.title: Centralization risk due to owner's ability to activate stake pool and change pool limit
findings.description: The smart contract has an active ownership which poses a centralization risk, allowing the owner to activate stake pool and change pool limit.
